column4: Does having ssh-daemon on make my linux pc-server more vulnerable to attacks?
unless you're behind a firewall or NAT-router, yes.
how could i tell if i am behind a NAT-router?
well do you use a router?
iptables is a firewall.
right now, I can connect to your IP on SSH port
only if passwords are picked in  dumb fashion
What does that mean?
it means you're either not behind a firewall/NAT or you are forwarding SSH port to your machine
if you meant the password note: it means picking too simple passwords
an even better bet is you pick a hard password for your users, restrict ssh to only the users you need and possibly disable password login
unless a hacker knows your password, you're right safe.
the whole world uses SSH. Just make sure you know how to harden it.
does the prompt say stefano server?
it doesn't say anything
you don't get that info prior to logging in
not the easy way I think...
it's better to make a user only for external logins
and give that user a really tough password
you should take a look at /etc/ssh/sshd_config, especially AllowUser(s?)
great... ill take a look at it. Does man pages have more info on it?
AllowUser
tons!
you can do an awful lot with ssh.
